titleStmt.title: Variants of Raising of a in pre-tonic (unstressed) closed syllable before ā - CaCāC
titleStmt.author: Veronika Engler

sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for Raising of a in pre-tonic (unstressed) open syllable before ā - CaCāC.

item.label: a > i zimān
item.desc: also includes raising to u or ə in different environments

item.label: a > a and i become schwa for the Maghreb

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Elderly (70+), Old (60-70) and some middle age speakers show consistent raising of short medial a in unstressed open syllable.

Young speakers and some middle-aged speakers do not show raising of short medial a in unstressed open syllable, but rather either they keep the a or they elide it, unlike Elderly (70+), Old (60-70) and some middle age speakers who do show consistent raising.

Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:55 notes that: "In Bedouin dialects, *a in pretonic syllable or the first open syllable of a word is raised to /i/ or /u/ in the environment of front consonants, respectively labials. In sedentary dialects this shift is rather restricted to some cases

Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:55 notes that: "In Bedouin dialects, *a in pretonic syllable or the first open syllable of a word is raised to /i/ or /u/ in the environment of front consonants, respectively labials. In sedentary dialects this shift is rather restricted to some cases

Behnstedt and Geva-Kleinberger 2019:63 note in a section entitled Fronting of *a in CaCāCīC: “This is merely a phenomenon in Bedouin dialects. We will omit a map". They however mention specific examples of three tribes: Ǧawāmīs, Sawāʕid and Kaʕbiyye. We give these examples in the entries corresponding to these three tribes.

Deducted from examples.

Pickett (2005:54) notes that "The gutturals ġ, x, ʕ, ḥ, h and ʔ, restrain the raising of a following vowel, as does one of the continuants, l, n and r. This phenomenon is often referred to as the 'Short Vowel Raising Rule'."

Pickett (2005:54) notes that "The gutturals ġ, x, ʕ, ḥ, h and ʔ, restrain the raising of a following vowel, as does one of the continuants, l, n and r. This phenomenon is often referred to as the 'Short Vowel Raising Rule'."

Pickett (2005:54) notes that "The gutturals ġ, x, ʕ, ḥ, h and ʔ, restrain the raising of a following vowel, as does one of the continuants, l, n and r. This phenomenon is often referred to as the 'Short Vowel Raising Rule'."

Pickett (2005:54) notes that "The gutturals ġ, x, ʕ, ḥ, h and ʔ, restrain the raising of a following vowel, as does one of the continuants, l, n and r. This phenomenon is often referred to as the 'Short Vowel Raising Rule'."

Pickett (2005:54) notes that "The gutturals ġ, x, ʕ, ḥ, h and ʔ, restrain the raising of a following vowel, as does one of the continuants, l, n and r. This phenomenon is often referred to as the 'Short Vowel Raising Rule'."

Pickett (2005:54) notes that "The gutturals ġ, x, ʕ, ḥ, h and ʔ, restrain the raising of a following vowel, as does one of the continuants, l, n and r. This phenomenon is often referred to as the 'Short Vowel Raising Rule'."
Younes (2013: 39) notes that raising tends to be blocked by preceding guttural consonants: "La présence d’une gutturale a tendance à inhiber l’élévation de /a/".
Younes (2014: 364) notes that raising is blocked by preceding guttural consonants: "Comme escompté, les consonnes /ʾ/, /ʿ/, /x/, /ġ/, /h/ et /ḥ/ inhibent totalement l’élévation".

In general, the short vowel seems to be retained in loanwords, e.g. taqāfa 'culture'
Deduced from examples
/c/ represents the IPA [c], the voiceless palatal plosive.
This raising "is current, but is concluded to be optional, since it is often absent in more careful speech" (R. De Jong)
Raising to i or u mostly when not followed by l or r and not preceded by ʔ.
This raising "is current, but is concluded to be optional, since it is often absent in more careful speech" (R. De Jong)
